semantic_title: History Z Codes - Personal and Family History Coding Guidelines
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 21. Factors Influencing Health Status > c. Status > 4) History (of)

content.full_text: There are two types of history Z codes, personal and family. Personal history codes explain a patient's past medical condition that no longer exists and is not receiving any treatment, but that has the potential for recurrence, and therefore may require continued monitoring. Family history codes are for use when a patient has a family member(s) who has had a particular disease that causes the patient to be at higher risk of also contracting the disease. Personal history codes may be used in conjunction with follow-up codes and family history codes may be used in conjunction with screening codes to explain the need for a test or procedure. History codes are also acceptable on any medical record regardless of the reason for visit. A history of an illness, even if no longer present, is important information that may alter the type of treatment ordered. The reason for the encounter (for example, screening or counseling) should be sequenced first and the appropriate personal and/or family history code(s) should be assigned as additional diagnos(es). (Evidence: pg no: 97-98, L30-L33)
content.summary: History Z codes include personal history (past conditions with recurrence potential) and family history (family member conditions increasing patient risk), used for monitoring and risk assessment (Evidence: pg no: 97-98, L30-L33)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Personal history codes explain past medical conditions that no longer exist, are not receiving treatment, but have potential for recurrence requiring monitoring (Evidence: pg no: 97, L31)
detailed_rules.explanation: These codes capture significant past medical conditions that, while resolved, remain clinically relevant due to recurrence risk and need for ongoing surveillance (Evidence: pg no: 97, L31)
common_applications: History of cardiovascular disease affecting treatment decisions

detailed_rules.rule_text: Family history codes are used when family members have had diseases that increase the patient's risk of contracting the same disease (Evidence: pg no: 97, L32)
detailed_rules.explanation: These codes document family medical history that places the patient at higher risk, justifying enhanced screening or preventive measures (Evidence: pg no: 97, L32)
common_applications: Family history of cancer requiring enhanced screening

detailed_rules.rule_text: The reason for the encounter should be sequenced first and history codes assigned as additional diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 98, L33)
detailed_rules.explanation: History codes typically serve as supporting information rather than the primary reason for the encounter (Evidence: pg no: 98, L33)
common_applications: Screening encounter with family history as additional diagnosis
Counseling visit with personal history as supporting information

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify if patient has personal or family history relevant to encounter

Step 4: Add appropriate history codes as additional diagnoses
